CatDescriptText: Mrs. Mary Ellison, domestic, East End and Mr. Ralph Meyers, industrial designer, Warrendale, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 4, 1961, pg. 7 with question "Who do you think is largely responsible for Negro topflight entertainers being denied the chance to headline the Grade A television shows--the sponsors, the advertising agencies, or the general public?" Mrs. Ellison's answer reads: "I guess the public is at fault.  They don't seem to cater to colored and support them.  I don't know why, because colored entertainers are just as good, if not better than whites."  Mr. Meyers' answer reads: "You are talking to a person who does not have a television set in his home.  And the reason is, because I feel that the level of entertainment is at such a mediocre point, that we don't care to spend the time or to have our children spend the time to watch..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Mary Ellison wearing dark headpiece and coat with single button at collar, standing  in front of Dimling's Candy, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Ralph Meyers wearing eyeglasses, dark patterned necktie, and light colored coat, standing on sidewalk
